Yet more updates to come on the Supreme Court's gay marriage arguments, courtesy of @LawrenceHurley and @JoanBiskupic.
Kennedy agreed with Scalia on the science, saying it is so new, but he said kids in California want full status for their gay parents.
Scalia, on whether kids of gay couples are harmed: "It's certainly true that there is no scientific answer on that at this point in time."
Cooper said no, he's not conceding that. Kennedy, again: "Then it seems to me you have to address Justice Kagan's question."
Cooper answered, but Kennedy wasn't satisfied. Kennedy to Cooper: "Are you conceding the point there is no harm or degradation?"
Kagan pressed Cooper on how gay marriages "harm" opposite-sex couples. "How does this cause and effect work?"
Cooper had a bit of a short coughing fit about 10:18, just as he turned to the merits.
Breyer early on got into the mix on standing, pressing Cooper on whether "public actions" may be heard in the federal system.
On standing, Roberts at one point waved off the California high court's view: "A state can't authorize anyone to proceed in federal court."
Cooper said the high court should defer on the standing question to the California Supreme Court's findings.
Charles Cooper was interrupted during his first sentence or two of the argument. Roberts suggested he begin with standing, not the merits.
Updated story coming shortly on the first half of today's Supreme Court arguments.
